title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can be used towards qualified health insurance, is refundable, and advanceable. To claim the HCTC, taxpayers must be in specific eligibility groups and not enrolled in certain types of health insurance. To claim the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), taxpayers must be in one of two eligibility groups: recipients of certain benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program and individuals aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). TAA helps workers who lose their jobs due to international trade, and if certified, they are eligible for the HCTC based on receipt of certain TAA benefits. Workers who lose their jobs due to international trade can petition the U.S. Department of Labor to establish eligibility for Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) benefits. If certified, they may receive the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) based on receipt of certain TAA benefits such as Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) or Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA). Workers who lose their jobs due to international trade can receive Trade Readjustment Allowance (TRA) after exhausting unemployment insurance (UI). They can also qualify for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) while collecting TRA or UI. Additionally, workers aged 50 and older may be eligible for Reemployment Trade Adjustment Assistance (RTAA) which provides a wage supplement for up to two years. Alternative Trade Adjustment Assistance (ATAA) is a similar wage-insurance program. Eligibility for the HCTC is limited to individuals receiving TAA benefits. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) is available to individuals who receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. Workers certified for TAA but receiving only job-search assistance are not eligible for HCTC. To receive a PBGC benefit, individuals must have worked for a firm with a defined-benefit pension plan taken over by PBGC. PBGC assumes control of plans to protect participants' interests. The PBGC assumes control of defined-benefit pension plans to protect participants' interests and pays pensions using plan assets and insurance reserves. Individuals receiving PBGC-paid pensions can qualify for the HCTC if they are at least 55 years old and not yet eligible for Medicare. The HCTC program has eligibility limitations for these individuals. The HCTC program has eligibility limitations for individuals receiving PBGC-paid pensions. Those eligible must be at least 55 years old and not yet eligible for Medicare. Restrictions include not being enrolled in certain health plans or programs like Medicare Part B, FEHBP, Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare Part A, or U.S. military health coverage. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must not be enrolled in Medicare Part A, Medicare Part B, FEHBP, Medicaid, CHIP, or U.S. military health coverage. They also cannot be incarcerated or claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. The HCTC can be used for health insurance covering the taxpayer, their spouse, and dependents. Family members must meet the same eligibility criteria as the taxpayer and can receive the HCTC for up to two years. Children of divorced or separated parents are treated as dependents of the custodial parent for tax purposes. Qualifying family members can receive the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) for up to two years under certain circumstances. The HCTC can only be used to cover part of the premium for qualified health insurance, limited to 11 categories of coverage. Four of these categories are automatically qualified health plans that individuals can elect without state involvement. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can only be used to cover part of the premium for qualified health insurance, limited to 11 categories of coverage. Four categories are automatically qualified health plans that individuals can elect without state involvement, while the other seven categories are state-qualified health plans. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can only be used to cover part of the premium for qualified health insurance, limited to 11 categories of coverage. The seven state-qualified health plans include options like state-based continuation coverage, coverage through a state high-risk pool, and coverage under a state arrangement with a private-sector health care purchasing pool. State-qualified health plans must provide four consumer protections to qualifying individuals, defined as HCTC-eligible individuals with three months of prior creditable coverage and no significant break in coverage. State-qualified health plans must guarantee issue coverage to qualifying individuals who meet specific eligibility criteria, including no significant break in coverage and three months of prior creditable coverage. These plans must also provide coverage without denial based on preexisting conditions, offer premiums at the same rate as other similar individuals, and ensure benefits are comparable to those for others. Certain types of coverage, such as accident or disability income, are not considered qualified health insurance. The HCTC program ensures that benefits for qualifying individuals are similar to others, with certain types of coverage not considered qualified health insurance. The IRS administers the program, with involvement from federal and state agencies. The HCTC program, administered by the IRS, involves multiple federal and state agencies. The Department of the Treasury handles advance payments, the IRS reviews tax returns, and DOL and PBGC help identify eligible individuals. State entities like SWAs also play a role in administering benefits. The Department of Labor (DOL) coordinates the One-Stop Career Center system, providing services to assist job seekers and distribute information about benefits like the HCTC. State workforce agencies (SWAs) administer unemployment and TAA benefits, while the PBGC and IRS identify potential HCTC beneficiaries and provide relevant information for eligibility. SWAs mail HCTC information packets to eligible TAA beneficiaries, including an eligibility certificate. The IRS sends program kits to individuals identified by SWAs and PBGC. The HCTC eligibility certificate identifies individuals potentially eligible for the tax credit. The IRS mails program kits to eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance, who can claim the credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The HCTC is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Other tax credits do not affect HCTC eligibility. The HCTC is a refundable tax credit that allows taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, even if they have little or no tax liability. It does not affect eligibility for other tax credits, except for the premium tax credit under the Affordable Care Act. In 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. Preliminary data for 2016 showed an increase in submissions. The IRS published summary statistics in its 2014 Statistics of Income report regarding the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC). For tax year 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. In 2016, 13,015 e-filed tax returns claimed the credit. Taxpayers claiming the HCTC after the tax year ends must complete Form 8885 and attach it to their Form 1040, including invoices and proof of payment for qualified health insurance. The credit amount reduces taxes owed and is refundable, with any excess amount refunded to the taxpayer. To receive the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must provide invoices and proof of payment for qualified health insurance. The credit reduces taxes owed and is refundable. Advance payments are available by registering with the HCTC program and enrolling in a qualified health insurance plan. Payments for the monthly premium are split between the individual and Treasury, with Treasury covering 72.5% of the premium. Taxpayers pay 27.5% of the monthly premium for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), with Treasury covering the remaining 72.5%. Payments are sent to Treasury, who then pays 100% of the premium to the individuals' health insurance plans.
